question_text: Why does the addition of magnesium (Mg) to boron composites significantly reduce ignition delay and enhance combustion efficiency, and what are the underlying heat transfer and chemical kinetic mechanisms?
standard_answer: Magnesium addition reduces boron ignition delay and enhances combustion efficiency through exothermic pre-ignition reactions and improved heat transfer. Mg ignites at lower temperatures (~924 K) than boron (~2348 K melting point), releasing heat that raises the local temperature, accelerating boron oxidation kinetics. The Mg-B composite undergoes a two-stage oxidation process: first, Mg oxidizes exothermically, increasing mass by 27.5% and providing thermal energy; second, boron oxidizes with an 82.7% mass increase. Chemically, Mg combustion produces MgO, which may react with B2O3 to form lower-melting compounds, reducing the oxide barrier's effectiveness. Thermally, the higher thermal conductivity of Mg-coated particles (e.g., B@Mg) improves heat distribution, reducing thermal gradients and promoting uniform ignition. Experiments show B@Mg with 8 wt.% Mg reduces ignition delay by 28.4% compared to pure boron, due to these combined exothermic and conductive effects.

original_text.1: Mg ignites more easily than B, and because of its exothermicity, the addition of Mg can promote the ignition and combustion of B powder and increase heat release at lower temperatures.
original_text.2: The thermal oxidation of B-Mg mixture with the Mg to B mole ratio equal to 1/2 occurs through a two-stage process. The temperature range and shape of the exothermic peak of the first stage are close to the oxidation and melting processes of Mg powder, during which the mass increases by 27.5%. The mass of the second stage of oxidation increases by 82.7%, which results from B oxidation.
original_text.3: B@Mg had a significantly decreased ignition delay time, and that the Mg coating accelerated the burning of B. The ignition delay time of B@Mg (8 wt.%) was 28.4% lower than that of B0.
